problem.tex: Let $\gamma(t)=e^{it}, 0\leq t\leq 2\pi$. Let $f(x)$ be any odd function analytic on a neighborhood of $\overline{B}_1(0)$. Evaluate \[\int_\gamma\frac{f(z)}{z^3}dz.\]

solution.tex: We can solve this with the residue theorem. Because $f$ is odd it has a power series representation of only odd terms, \[f(z)=a_1z+a_3z^3+a_5z^5+\cdots.\] The Laurent expansion of $\frac{f(z)}{z^3}$ can be found by dividing each term by $z^3$, giving \[f(z)=\frac{a_1}{z^2}+a_3+a_5z^2+\cdots.\] This function has no residue because there is no $z^{-1}$ term, so by the residue theorem the integral vanishes.
